A monkey self harming isn't evidence of harm from a surgical procedure, nor is it evidence of particularly bad treatment. It is unfortunately a common occurrence in lab monkeys, being caged and operated on is distressing no matter how well treated and ethically the research is conducted. It's just going to happen.  Also I'd imagine most of the monkeys involved in these procedures were terminated at the end of each study, tissue analysis on brains to determine the impact of the surgical implants and procedures can't be done on a live brain.  You can debate the scientific merit of the studies, Musk's goals and influence in doing these studies, and investigate the facilities actually carrying out the studies to see if they aren't up to snuff, but don't knock animal studies as a concept because a high profile shitbag is funding some.

As a wide-eyed undergrad, I definitely believed every sensationalized headline claiming a Brave New (West)World was just around the corner. Animal testing is not just used to test new frontier formulas. It is most frequently used to test every single batch of cleaning supplies that gets made. Bleach has been around since the beginning of time, everyone knows what it does, but except in countries where animal testing is banned, EVERY batch of new bleach made gets poured into the eyes of animals, gets large quantities tubed into their stomachs, etc.  If a product is "tested on humans" that means the product doesn't contain any ingredients that are required by law to be tested.  The reason why it is safe for humans to "test" is because it does not contain dangerous chemicals, not because they already know how the chemicals react. I work for a company developing technology to try and improve manufacturing for cell and gene therapies. There are currently some seriously big obstacles to overcome for personalised medicine, especially things like CAR-T therapy which are manufactured in-vitro, but for sure it's going to be the future in the next decade or so. The engineering challenges are definitely there but they are solvable - it's just a matter of time.  The potential that gene therapies have to treat and in many cases cure things like diabetes and cancer is phenomenal and really people are still just beginning to figure out what's possible. Once the industry starts getting more standardised platforms and the costs stop being so prohibitively high, there'll be an explosion forward in research, clinical trials and new therapies being brought to market.

Because it is training your adaptive immune system to seek and destroy an antigen, just like any other vaccine. The only difference is the antigen is on your own cells, and it has been mutated to no longer resemble it's normal form. Since the mutations that lead to cancer are often numerous and complex, everyone has different antigens and so everyone needs a slightly different version of the vaccine. They are both vaccines, but one (HPV) is prophylactic meaning you take it to prevent a disease while the other is therapeutic meaning you take it to treat a disease. The same is true for many things, for example if you get a large cut the doctor will give you prophylactic antibiotics even though its not infected, they will also give antibiotics therapeutically to treat an infection. So it's like that but for vaccines.

It's a good lesson in learning to read between the lines of press releases like this. Note this piece doesn't actually describe any of the results except in the vaguest of terms - "the results were remarkable" or "improved in key physical outcomes". By how much? In what groups? At what dose? Is it clinically meaningful? When you don't see answers to these types of obvious questions, it is a warning sign. This news, if correct and functional, is massive. Not because of animal rights or anything like that, but because of how insanely inaccurate animal testing is. There's no telling how many cures or real solutions just didn't work on mice or whatever else that would have been perfect in humans. There's also way too many drugs that pass animal testing that go on to harm humans or be ineffective. As long as this is a viable (financially and functionally useful) human analog, then the benefit to humanity could be vast in both monetary terms (a lot less testing) and life.

Synthetic biology is a tool for creation, but forward genetics investigating how existing things work. It's also incredibly different designing new yeast and malaria (based on forward and backward genetic research), to scaling the process up to multicellular organisms and the vertebrates. Synthetic biology is absolutely a tech of the future, but not a tech of the near future, and it certainly won't remove the need for in vivo genetic manipulation. In a similar vein, bioinformatics can help us make predictions, but can't test hypotheses, and therefore won't remove the need for wet lab experiments.

That's why you run a Phase 3 vaccine trial. You find people at risk for Ebola, in this case contacts of known Ebola cases. Then, you randomly vaccinate some people and don't vaccinate others (actually, you vaccinate them later, but same idea). At the end of the trial, you compare the number of Ebola cases across the groups. If the vaccine works, there will be few or no cases among those vaccinated, and, among the unvaccinated, there will be more cases. That is why it is so hard to run such a trial. There needs to be ongoing transmission, and you need to have enrolled those people at risk in your study. Very tricky! But you would never purposefully expose people to Ebola. They do expose non-human primates though.

Yes, it is an ethical issue.  Vaccine testing gets complicated, because a simple experimental design that has the greatest statistical power would mean having a control group who, like the treatment group, need the vaccine because they are likely to be exposed and get the disease.  With something like ebola, you might be flipping a coin (so to speak) to decide whether the person in front of you will live. More complicated trial designs can ultimately vaccinate everyone, and then you can analyze the time structure of the infections that occur to see how many the vaccine likely prevented.

To add to the many correct direct answers to your question about how cancer charities support developing treatment, they can also help out quite considerably on the patient side.  If you have a rare cancer, or one that is effectively untreatable within the skills of your local hospital or any they can refer you to, it's not necessarily within the remit of the health professionals working with you to know about and help you explore every avenue that's available to you. If you're a patient where basically your only shot at treatment is an experimental clinical trial, you're often better off contacting cancer charities for your area of cancer because they're much more likely to have their finger on the pulse on what trials may be available to you, especially if they're taking place halfway round the world.

That's only for higher grade, non-invasive tumours - especially if there are multiple tumours. Recurrent bladder tumours may be treated with the BCG vaccine as well.  When I had bladder cancer, the tumour was removed and I was given one shot of chemo (mytomicin) into the bladder. It's left in the bladder for an hour. I left hospital the next day.  I was lucky, the histology results showed that my cancer was non-invasive and low grade. I didn't need any further treatment. I did have to have regular cystoscopies though. I've been cancer free since 2006. You could operate testing regimes in high risk individuals and families. Catching the cancer is the key. At an early stage, bladder cancer has an excellent prognosis, but it does have a high recurrence rate, hence the regular cystoscopies. Having a test that does away with cystoscopies would be brilliant.

Actually for MS they do a lot of HSCT, which is when they take your own stem cells. They give you chemo to suppress your immune system and give you medication that makes you produce more stem cells. They then extract those stem cells from you, give you extremely high dose chemo to kill off the rest of your immune system, and then put your own stem cells back into you which become your new immune system.  The reason why it's so hard to get in the US is a lot of healthcare politics. It's also definitely a last resort kind of thing. Not something you would do for someone who has MS that responds to other treatments.

For diseases like cancer there is no placebo arm. Instead the current gold standard of therapy is tested against the experimental drug to show whether the new drug is an improvement over the therapy we have now. Studies can be concluded early if the results are clear enough that it would be unethical to continue patients on the current therapy when they would be significantly better off in the experimental group. The only times a placebo is used is when there is no standard of care other than supportive treatment.

I think the title and press release are misleading. This simulation is great fit identifying potential master-switches, but didn't remove the need to experientially test whether they work. On to of this, there's the assumption that any cell type can be converted into any other cell type directly, which may not be the case, and may not be practical for all applications. I believe that induced pluripotent Stem cells will still be important.

Yes, you are mostly correct. However, the "screens" are rogue proteins that can no longer do their job properly.  There's a specific protein in your body, p53, that functions as a tumor suppressor. When this protein mutates, it can become an oncogene that allows cancer cells to grow unchecked. The protein will give a signal to your immune system that says "no problems here." If p53 fails, the tumor can be detected by your immune system if it expresses some other mutation that sends a signal saying "I'm an invader." There are other proteins that can suppress cancer cells when p53 fails, but it's not their primary function.

I work for a company developing technology to try and improve manufacturing for cell and gene therapies. There are currently some seriously big obstacles to overcome for personalised medicine, especially things like CAR-T therapy which are manufactured in-vitro, but for sure it's going to be the future in the next decade or so. The engineering challenges are definitely there but they are solvable - it's just a matter of time.  The potential that gene therapies have to treat and in many cases cure things like diabetes and cancer is phenomenal and really people are still just beginning to figure out what's possible. Once the industry starts getting more standardised platforms and the costs stop being so prohibitively high, there'll be an explosion forward in research, clinical trials and new therapies being brought to market.

The actual cost is in the ballpark of 1 million for a one time, likely curative treatment. The alternative treatment, enzyme replacement, costs over 100k per year for life. Due to the long term cost benefit, in many instances insurance companies contributed heavily. The cost involves weeks of hospital stay, bone marrow mobilization, production of the clinical grade lentiviral vector, the lab team that does the processing of the mobilized peripheral blood stem cells, sterile reagents that are certified for GMP work, re-administering the cells to the patient, and follow-up visits to detail the safety and efficacy of the treatment. A lot goes in to this.

I work in cancer clinical trials, and they often don't have a control group, especially when targeting subjects at a therapeutic dead end. Basically the logic is that if you're trying to get your new drug to replace a standard treatment, you have to prove in a blinded trials that new is better than current treatment. In cancer, the majority of trials target patients in whose the standard treatment failed so there's no control group to use.

For the most part, chemo works specifically because it's so devastating. In a case like this, it basically kills out as much of your bone marrow as possible so you can replace it all with new marrow (which contains the stem cells mentioned in the title). If your immune cells are what's causing the problem, as is strongly suspected for MS, you want as little of your bone marrow left as possible at the time of transplant, since that's where your immune cells come from. You basically want a complete reboot of the immune system from scratch. The side effects associated with chemo are in large part caused by the fact that you're killing bone marrow and other rapidly dividing cells, so it's basically an unavoidable issue, at least with any current technology.

There's actually several protocols and regulations for testing in any animals that have intelligences over a certain threshold,  or are analogous to humans, such as apes and monkeys--even cephalopods, porpoises, and canines in some cases. Rat and porcine tissues, cells, and receptors are extremely similar to humans, so many trials just involve using pigs or rats. There's less paperwork involved and generally you get comparable results to what you'd find in humans.

Vaccines in the sense of creating immunity still rely on certain factors to work though. If there's no mutant protein expression on cell surfaces it's harder to efficaciously target cancers. If the mutation causes a healthy receptor to overexpress or targets matrix secretions then you inevitably train off target action of the vaccine too.  It's a really promising field but cancers still provide challenges even for mRNA vaccines

This precaution isn't necessarily specific to the utilization of AHSCT in treating MS. Autologous Stem Cell Transplants are used to treat a variety of blood and marrow disorders and these treatments have undergone comprehensive studies, indicating there is a chance of mortality during those treatments. The reason it is utilized in other areas of medicine is because in those circumstances, the potential risks are worth the potential benefits as there are not as many options available to treat. With Multiple Sclerosis, there are numerous different treatment options available, each with potential side effects and potential benefits.  Because MS gets a relatively large amount of research money compared to some of the diseases that ASCT is traditionally used for, potential advancements in transplant medicine could be an outcome helping many areas outside of MS specifically.

This is specifically only a treatment for hair loss caused by alopecia because it's focusing on the primary cause of the symptoms. Alopecia is an autoimmune disease, the hair loss is due to the immune system attacking hair follicles. If you stop the immune system attacking, presumably hair growth occurs as normal, but that's far more complicated and difficult than it sounds. No one should read this and get excited about a new treatment for male pattern baldness. That's something else entirely. This treatment sounds like it's not dissimilar to other autoimmune treatments. Arthritis is inflammation, auto immune diseases also cause abnormal inflammation, so certain medicines will end up treating both things. Humira for example treats arthritis and Crohn's disease.

Prions are actually proteins with a pathogenic folded configuration. The structure and function of a protein molecule depends on how it literally folds into a complex glob in biological systems. Sometimes normally healthy  proteins can "misfold" into a destructive configuration. Prions are misfolded proteins that can cause other similar proteins to misfold quickly. The new misfolded proteins are also pathogenic and the chain reaction continues throughout nervous tissue. This results in tissue crystallization and many tiny holes in the affected brain. Death ensues.

I should have mentioned that in the case of Alzheimer's specifically, it has been a huge mystery whether the symptoms of the disease are the cause, or an effect. We thought for a long time that the amyloid plaques that gum up these neurons is obviously a cause of the disease, but there have also been hypotheses advanced that these plaques are "protective" and sequester nasty proteins into a state where they can't be harmful. I've been out of the field for several years, but as far as I know, the debate rages on today.

In any case, genetic manipulations are incredibly dangerous because they can have prolonged delayed systemic effects. In particular, your body has been training the immune system for decades to avoid autoimmune aggression. Any new transgenic protein can cause such a powerful immune response that no inflammation blocker can cope with the immune response. Have you heard anything about multiple sclerosis?  Anyone who is professionally involved in genetic engineering knows from experience how unstable modern technologies are. The creation of any gene therapy is the work of dozens and hundreds of highly qualified specialists. But any fool can inject himself with some DNA.

nope.   type 1 is an absolute deficiency of self insulin production due to an immune-mediated destruction of the body's own insulin-producing cells.  it happens pretty fast.  type 1 patients need external insulin or they'll die. type 2 starts as an insensitivity to a person's own insulin, but also results in much of their insulin-producing cells being impaired or lost over time....it happens slow.  some type 2 patients eventually need external insulin, but many don't also.

It is even more complicated than that.  Once a retrovirus like HIV infects you by DNA splicing, it could return at any time, forever.  Immunotherapy is appealing because your body just identifies and eliminates the virus once it reappears. Think about shingles - it is similar in that it could respawn in your nerve cells at any time.  People live most of their lives without it, but it can spring back when your immune system is down.  HIV is likely to be similar to that.

Annual blood test can help. My husband's multiple myeloma was caught early by an eye exam (he was in his early 50s). The eye doc saw 'sparkes, star-like points' in the back of his eye. The doc said to get a blood test asap. He did. That blood test showed enough markers out of range that they did an extensive blood test. 19 out of 30 results were out of range. Either too low or too high. Almost exactly a year later, chemo, tons of drugs, so much pain and transplant of his own treated marrow, he reached remission. Five years so far. There is no cure for multiple myeloma. He will get it again. We live with this.

I did a rotation in an Alzheimer's lab, and got the impression that it's entirely possible, if not likely, that the classic model of Alzheimer's might be reversed. In other words, it may be that plaques and tangles are the brain's way of sequestering toxic proteins, rather than the plaques and tangles actually causing the detrimental neurological effects. This is something that's commonly written in Alzheimer's reviews, so it's not my personal opinion, but it does seem that the field has been slow to seriously consider the possibility that all the research of the last few decades has been backwards.

I actually perform this testing almost daily in our lab, and yeah, they sample the medicine at various parts of the creation process and we test the samples. If the sample are clean they they continue on to the next part of the process until you eventually finish up with the bulk drug substance - of which that we also test a sample. If everything is good to go, then it heads to the filling station where it gets packaged in the stuff that goes straight to the pharmacy

SIRP- alpha is a protein that is produced by many of the bodies cells. It interacts with another protein (CD47) to let the body know it is one of its own cells and should not be 'eaten' by any immune cells. This stops any immune cells (macrophages in this case) from eating the cancerous cells. The macrophages with SIRP- alpha deletion will not recognise the cancerous cells as 'own' and will therefore 'eat' and destroy them

Happens all the time. When the compound shows high toxicity or lack of effect the compound is generally dropped without testing it in humans, because of obvious reasons. However, the drug wouldnt have necessarily been toxic in humans. There are examples of compounds which are highly toxic to some animals but are well tolerated by other animals. I always like the example of vincristine. It's a chemo regularly used in humans but also in animals. Humans do tolerate it when it's used as a chemo, however dogs tolerate much higher doses of the stuff. A normal vincristine chemo regiment for dogs would kill humans. Source, halfway through my masters biopharmaceutical sciences and my dad's a vet.

I always like the example of vincristine. It's a chemo regularly used in humans but also in animals. It binds to CD40 Ligand (CD40L) on t cells, blocking their ability to bind to CD40 receptors on antigen presenting cells like B cell and dendritic cells. The net result is reduced "crosstalk" between cells and reduced T cell and B cell activity and reduced inflammation. Importantly, this will reduce the ability of highly specific and long lasting antibodies from being formed, which are detrimental to long term survival or transplanted organs.

It's not mine, it's just the one that is accepted by the majority and is massively dependent on what is explored and how the authors are exploring it. At the bottom there is expert opinion and case studies, above that is retrospective cohort studies, followed by prospective cohort studies. After those it's the RCTs, starting with unblinded, followed by single blinding and finally double blinding. The highest standard of evidence is a meta-analysis of a number of these studies. I can't stress enough how reductive this list is but if bias is eliminated and the group's are representative then it's a good rule of thumb.

By breeding for it. Lab mice as a collective have both the worst genetics, and the best available treatments, of any species. The mice in question are specifically bred to have the same defects as humans with the disease would. Mice don't get Alzheimer's naturally, we specifically make rats that way to experiment on them. We're not really searching for an Alzheimer's cure, we're searching for a cure to fix the defects of a mouse that we engineered to work that way. If it works for mice (it occasionally does), we try it on other animals. If they don't fall over dead, we try it on some healthy humans. If they don't fall over dead either (they occasionally do), we finally try it on sick people to see if it actually works as intended.

Also the argument of "a cancer patient cured is a patient lost" doesn't make sense. Cancer can come back multiple times in a single person, it doesn't magically just disappear forever if it's cured once. I should have mentioned that in the case of Alzheimer's specifically, it has been a huge mystery whether the symptoms of the disease are the cause, or an effect. A clinical trial in Alzheimer's is a very expensive thing to run (heterogeneous disease, so you need lots of participants) and slow development (so you need to run it for a long time). Oncology is where you find all sorts of semi-crazy stuff being tried, because the course of the disease is rapid and the endpoints are easier to measure.

The opposite is actually more likely. HIV suppresses the immune system which increases your risk of catching other diseases. Those who do not get tested or use protection also tend to be the ones unaware of their HIV-positive status, which makes them the people most at risk of other STIs. Furthermore, HIV does not spread uniformly. Those most at risk are the people who do not use protection, and thus already at elevated risk of other STIs. They tend to act as "hot-spots" for STIs and thus reducing their risk of catching other STIs, even by a small amount, can have a large effect on the overall infection rate. Since they are already not taking precautions, it is unlikely that their rate of infections will increase much from more risky behaviour.

The therapy is an antibody.  Normally in a vaccination, you will inject a foreign antigen into the body to which your body mounts an immune response in the form of antibodies.  Your immune system remembers the antigen and destroys it if it enters your system again.   Here, they exogenously developed the antibodies against specific AD-associated proteins and tested them in the presence of various adjuvants (things that enhance immune response).  Thus, the action of the antibody is similar to the effects of a vaccine.

Albuterol (or salbutamol) is what is called a "short-acting beta-agonist" which opens up the lungs very quickly. Advair contains a long-acting beta-agonist, salmeterol, which also opens up the longs, but over the course of hours instead of seconds. It is better for preventing asthma symptoms. Advair also contains a long-acting corticosteroid, fluticasone (same drug as Flovent), which helps prevent inflammation.  Corticosteroids are first line treatment for prevention of asthma symptoms. Long-acting beta-agonists (LABA) are then added on if there is inadequate control. So if your asthma isn't controlled, your doctor may consider adding a LABA.

This is not completely true. A clinical trial in Alzheimer's is a very expensive thing to run (heterogeneous disease, so you need lots of participants) and slow development (so you need to run it for a long time). Oncology is where you find all sorts of semi-crazy stuff being tried, because the course of the disease is rapid and the endpoints are easier to measure.

Oh, I'm not defending big pharma at all. They have extremely slimy practices. But the notion that a cancer cure is being withheld because they could make more money is extremely dumb and makes no logical sense.

I can give a likely answer without having read the paper.  It's because it isn't a confounder.   You might at first think it is, as the occasion of serious disease (and the need for hospitalisation) is reduced in the vaccinated. However, if both groups have vaccinated people then the reduction in infection seriousness (and hospitalisation) cancels out allowing the groups to be compared.  This is basic experimental design and helps to save on cost and dropout of participants as more people might get vaccinated as part of their treatment (something you can't ethically stop them from doing).  If one group only had vaccinated people, that would be a problem, if both groups had no vaccinations it would be functionally identical to leaving vaccinated participants in.  Hope that helps explain why they weren't excluded.

For the most part, chemo works specifically because it's so devastating. In a case like this, it basically kills out as much of your bone marrow as possible so you can replace it all with new marrow (which contains the stem cells mentioned in the title). If your immune cells are what's causing the problem, as is strongly suspected for MS, you want as little of your bone marrow left as possible at the time of transplant, since that's where your immune cells come from. You basically want a complete reboot of the immune system from scratch. The side effects associated with chemo are in large part caused by the fact that you're killing bone marrow and other rapidly dividing cells, so it's basically an unavoidable issue, at least with any current technology.

Axolotl developmental biologist here, I can maybe clarify a bit more about "immortality".  They are definitely not by any means immortal as in can live forever. We all have it during development, but axolotls are like a glitch in the system where those populations are maintained a lot more abundant and pluripotent. Rapamycin works by binding to the protein FKBP12 which allows it to bind and inhibit mTORC1. mTORC1 is a super important signalling regulator that directly regulates a whole bunch of basic cellular processes and is implicated a all kinds of things like cancer. It's starting to be shown that it also accelerates aging when active which is why rapamycin is great. Rapamycin inhibits mTORC1 activity. The problem is rapamycin isn't actually a very good inhibitor. It only partially inhibits mTORC1. There are inhibitors that completely inhibit mTORC1 but the problem with them is they also inhibit mTORC2 which is very similar but performs a completely different function. The holy grail would a an mTORC1 specific inhibitor

Antibody titres are still a mediocre proxy for vaccine efficacy though. The antibody titres were measured by looking at how they bound to recombinant proteins, not flu virus. An antibody can bind but not prevent infection. A proper vaccine efficacy trial should look at how the rates of infection were changed as a result of vaccination, either by challenging (intentionally infecting) the patients or by using large numbers and seeing how they did during the flu season. Still, it's a good start and hopefully they can scrape up enough funding for a Phase II.

Because often in these types of studies, it's not a matter of one group getting treated and the control group just getting placebo. Often, the contol group is actually a previous, established treatment regime. Now, you might ask, "But if it's established, don't we already know the results? Why essentially repeat the experiment?" As I understand it, the answer is to control for the population being tested and the clinics providing the treatment. In the first case, the population in clinical trials centered in, say, LA may have a different response than that of one in New England. Similarly, different clinics may have different dosing procedures or even bedside manner, which can skew the results.

The SSRI paroxetine was the first medication to receive approval from the FDA in the United States for SAD. Which means the most studied in clinical trials. However, there is no evidence of superiority of one SSRI over another or SSRI v SNRI v MAOi. As an example, a clinical trial randomly assigned 440 patients with SAD to treatment with venlafaxine (75 to 225 mg daily extended release), paroxetine (20 to 50 mg daily), or placebo. After 12 weeks, response rates were similar in the venlafaxine and paroxetine groups, both of which were superior to placebo

This DNA technology utilizes 80 - 120 nucleotide long probes that are reverse complementary to the target sequence. The probes are biotinylated and isolated after they have captured the target sequence. When capturing DNA, individual probes are binding to 5 to 10 kilobase fragments.  This process works for RNA by utilizing reverse transcription to convert the RNA into DNA.  This process works with lysogenic virus. The viral DNA or RNA of lysogenic virus is very low so I'm not too sure on the specifics of how accurate and sensitive the assay is for lysogenic virus.  I'm not too sure on specific targets, my guess is that they are targeting promoter regions and things like capsule proteins and conserved domains. As someone who has worked in the aging field, aging is defined by the spectrum of declines you see as an organism gets older. Rapamycin, for example, is probably the best anti-aging agent that has been identified so far. It doesn't mean, necessarily, it must slow or reverse all processes associated with aging.

Clinical trials often have a series of checkpoints after the initial design.  Trials can be ended early if it is clear that the medication is effective and passes the significance threshold, as it is not considered ethical to keep the trial going at that point.   On the other hand, if the trial is showing the treatment is statistically worse than control since that trial is also unethical to maintain.  Another possibility is that the data up to the checkpoint will make it impossible to have a statistically valid result at the end of the trial, leading to the company to end the (very expensive!) trial to save money.

They aren't really "withholding" treatment. The whole point of doing a trial is to discover whether or not the drug works in the first place. In addition, if a drug shows a clear advantage over placebo early in the trial, the study is usually stopped and the placebo group is treated as well. This practice ensures that situations like the one in the article don't happen on a larger scale. But for the majority of trials, the treatment doesn't show an obvious advantage, and the trial is continued to gather as much data as possible. Just because one patient benefited and another didn't isn't a reason to abandon the entire scientific process altogether.

Because you want to eliminate as many confounding variables as possible.  One consequence is that, other than the administration of the drug to one group and the placebo to the other, it is absolutely vital that all other conditions be as similar as possible. This is an instance where both groups received identical treatment.  In addition, one group received a placebo and the other received an experimental drug.  It is possible that the experimental drug would help them in a statistically significant way, but it is also possible that it would have worsened many of their conditions, or had no effect whatsoever. This isn't homeopathy or the "natural" supplement market where manufacturers are get to claim anything they wish with absolutely no evidence of any kind.  These is real clinical trials where drugs are expected to demonstrate overwhelming evidence of efficacy and safety.

The one of the points of a clinic trial is to determine if a drug is safe, what side effects could possibly result, and if it works better than the standard of care (what doctors are already using to treat the disease).  When a drug is still experimental, the investigating doctors must still determine what causes any adverse event (like death). This way, it would at least be understood that the disease caused death and not the drug.  Also, a lot of new drugs (especially cancer ones) aren't even meant to prevent death, but merely to give a patient more time. If a person dies from their cancer, but they lived even months longer than similar patients who received the standard of care, then the drug still did its job.

Every molecule has a "label", some kind of ID barcode, that our defenses read. If the label isn't right, it is then categorized as an "enemy" and is destroyed. With autoinmune diseases, some of our real organs and tissues are mislabeled and then attacked as if they were an external enemy (maybe because this label looks too much like the one displayed by a past infection from a virus like Epstein Barr, this is not completely known). The vaccine aims to fix this by adding the right label to the molecules of these organs that are being attacked, and teaching the defenses to recognize them as friendly again so they stop with their bullshit.
